intro: Catostemma hirsutulum, commonly known as the hairy catostemma, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family, which includes coffee and gardenias, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered in fine hairs, giving it a fuzzy appearance. The showy, white to pinkish flowers bloom in late spring and attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.
